div.p: And the journals of Alexander the Great contained even trivial matters— Yet journals are not destined for trivial things alone, as annals are for serious ones; but contain all things promiscuously, whether of greater or of less concern— Bacon. De Augmentis Scientarum. Vol. 1. p. 30.

VI:15. My hour of rising— The morning was employed in finishing my despatch N. 46, to the Secretary of State— Then upon my Journal, which has involuntarily and insensibly run into arrears of more than three weeks. My Sons John and Charles came home from School. I walked with George across the fields to the Uxbridge Road—then over Hanwell Common and through a footpath to Ealing Church and home. By the Evening post, I received a Note from Lord Castlereagh, informing me that orders have been given to the Commissioners of the Customs and Excise for the Admission to Entry of the American Brig William and Cargo, on the same terms as if the Manifest had been regular— The Collector of the Customs at Liverpool had refused to admit this vessel to entry, because the Certificate of the Collector at Richmond, Virginia, upon the Manifest of Tobacco, was that the Captain had been qualified to it. The Act of Parliament required that the Manifest should have been sworn to; and it had been sworn to. But the Collector at Liverpool refused to receive the word qualified, as equivalent to sworn. My note to Lord Castlereagh about it was sent the first of last Month.— Received also a Letter from Mr William Couling, who is much alarmed with the fear of losing his prospect of being employed as a civil engineer, by the Governor of Virginia— He is afraid that the proposals which he gave me yesterday will be objected to, and prevent his obtaining the employment— He wishes them to be destroyed, and leave his compensation to what the Governor of Virginia himself shall judge proper. He likewise lets me into some unpleasant family Secrets of which he had not apprized me before.— This Evening I finished reading Walter Scott’s new Novel, the Antiquary. It is full of the same beauties and defects as Waverly and Guy Mannering; but is altogether the least excellent of the three. The fable is not well constructed—the incidents are too improbable and romantic. The character’s like all those of Scott’s drawing are moral giants, larger than the real life of nature— The picture of manners, and the free use of the Scottish dialect are much as in the two preceding works— The Antiquary, Edie Ochiltree the beggar, and old Elspeth are characters deeply interesting— The fishwoman Mucklebackit, the Post-mistress, Mailsetter, and the Innkeeperare subaltern characters well delineated— The rest have not much to recommend them.— Here as in the other instances there is too much countenance given to superstition— The Style is generally beautiful; the language full of force and energy; but as in all Scott’s prose writings occasionally quaint, and pedantic. It is remarkable that with his talent at drawing and colouring character, as well as of varying and enlivening dialogue, this author has never written for the Stage.

2. VI:30. This Morning I wrote Lord Castlereagh a Note, asking a permission from this Government for the exportation of rollers, and any Other Articles which may be wanted for the use of the Mint of the United States— Attended Church with my three Sons. Dr Nicholas read the Church Service for Whitsunday, including the Creed of St: Athanasius— Mr Millman preached from 1. Corinthians XII—10.11. “To another divers kinds of tongues; to another the interpretations of tongues. But all these worketh that one and the self-same Spirit, dividing to every man severally as he will.” I know not whether it be his fault or mine, but I can never give attention to Mr Millman’s Sermons— They are at once flashy and flat. I can hardly sit and hear them— Notice was given again that he had applied to be ordained as a Priest by the Bishop of Oxford on Trinity Sunday; that is next Sunday. There was also notice that to-morrow and the next day were to be kept as Holidays, and there would be religious service at the Church.— Mr Bourke the Danish Minister and his Lady came out and paid us a morning visit— Three of the Schoolmates of our Sons, Chichester and two Drury’s came and dined with them. I dined with Lord Holland, at Holland House, his Country Seat. It is about midway between the Brentford and Acton roads, and the entrance gate is at the side of the Kensington Turnpike— A very large Brick House, built in the Gothic Style, and four or five hundred years old. The library is in a central Hall which extends through the whole breadth of the house nearly two hundred feet long, but not more than thirty wide. The company were, Count and Countess Lieven, with whom there came a young English Lady—Count Beroldingen the Minister from the king of Wurtemberg—the Earl and Countess of Jersey, the Earl of March, eldest Son of the Duke of Richmond, Lord and Lady Granville, Sir James M’Intosh, and some other Gentlemen—eighteen sat down to table— The dinner was elegant; the wines choice; the dessert excellent, and might have seemed to me better; but that Madame Bourke an accomplished epicure had forewarned me that Lord Holland had the best Confectioner in London. The tone of Society was easy and agreeable— Lady Holland, was perfectly well bred; and by several unaffected marks of maternal attachment to her Son, Henry, a boy about twelve years of age who was present, bespoke a favourable opinion of her domestic character.— Lord Holland introduced the Earl of Jersey to me, at his request.— I sat between Count Lieven and Sir James M’Intosh at dinner, and had much Conversation with the latter, I had much also with Lord Holland after dinner, and was pleased with every part of the Conversation except my own— I offended Count and Countess Lieven, by bluntly saying, that I had never known such a thing as hot weather in Russia— I said two or three silly things to Sir James M’Intosh, and was altogether stiff and dull, beyond my usual measure— I asked Sir James M’Intosh if he was engaged upon a History of England— He told me he was—from the Revolution of 1688. He asked me, if I thought Dr Franklin had been sincere in the professions which he made here that he lamented the Revolution which was to separate the Colonies from Great Britain. which he said he did, the day before he last left London; even to tears— I told him I did not believe Dr Franklin wished for the Revolution— Nor Washington— He asked me if any of the leading men had— I said, perhaps my father—Samuel Adams—and James Otis.— He asked me if we had any popular writers in America— I said none— Any good History of the Revolution? I mentioned Gordon, Ramsey, and Marshall’s life of Washington. He said he had met in India, several masters of American Merchant Vessels; particularly from Salem; and found from them that America had two strong characters of English descent. A multitude of Newspapers and Stage Coaches— He also told me that he had last year introduced Walter Scott to Mr Clay—the first of his admirers that he had ever seen from Kentucky. He spoke of Scott’s three Novels, as admirable delineations of Scottish Manners and of characters— The construction of the Stories, to which I objected, he said was good for nothing— I thought there was in the last of the three no new picture of manners peculiarly Scottish. That is nothing which had not already been painted in Waverly and Guy Mannering. He mentioned the Antiquary himself.— I said the character was well drawn; but I did not perceive it to be peculiarly National. He said there was its pedantry; altogether Scotch— He was himself a Scotchman, and he understood that whatever contest there might be about other qualities, the palm of Pedantry was universally awarded to his Country. I observed, that there must be something very powerful in the principle of legitimacy, which made the Scotch nobility and gentry now proud of their rebellions in favour of the Stuart’s, and instanced the late addresses to Louis 18 in presenting him the Gaelic Ossian, and to the Prince Regent, also in Gaelic.— He said there was a sort of concession—“even in their errors”— I told him that I had great admiration for the principle of legitimacy, but I hoped he would give it the finishing stroke in his History— It was to me, like Octavius to Cicero—ornandus and tollendus— He said he should certainly not think it laudandus— It was merely the fashion of the day— Hume himself, in speaking of this principle
said it was admirable; inferior only to the more exalted principle of the rights of the People. Hoadley was made a Bishop in the reign of George the second; and Horsley, who somewhere called Hoadley the Republican Bishop, was made a Bishop in the reign of George the third—the first for preaching against the principle of legitimacy, and the second for preaching in favour of them— My conversation after dinner with Lord Holland, turned much on a comparison between the political Institutions of this Country, and of the United States. He enquired about our forms of Representation, of which I gave him an account; and told him that the result of them was that the very great proportion of our public men were lawyers— He said it was precisely the same here— The theory of their Representation in the House of Commons was bad, but perhaps no theory could produce a more perfect practical Representation of all Classes and interests of the community— Even the close boroughs, often served to bring in able and useful men, who by a more correct theory would find themselves excluded— Men of property could always make their way into Parliament by their wealth—men of family; such a man as the Earl of March, might go into the house of Commons for a few years in youth; to get experience of public business, and employ time to useful purpose; and there was no man of real talents who in one way or another could fail of obtaining sooner or later, admission into Parliament— But a great proportion of the House of Commons were lawyers; and most of the business of the house was done by them— In the house of Lords, all that was of any use was done by Lawyers. The great practical use of the House of Lords, was to be a check upon mischief that might be done by the Commons— Many Bill pass through that house, without sufficient Consideration— The Chancellor is under a sort of personal responsibility to examine, and stop them— His character depends upon it— He is at the head of the Nobility of the Country, and all that fudge; and his Consideration depends upon his keeping this vigilant eye over the proceedings of the Commons— All the ordinary business of the house therefore rest upon a lawyer— Lord Holland observed that from what he had heard, the most defective part of our Institutions in America was the judiciary; which I admitted— Count and Countess Lieven went away immediately after dinner. The Countess had an Evening party at her own house, to which we were invited— Mrs Adams was to come with the Carriage for me, about eleven, and I had specially directed the servants to send me in word when the Carriage came— But this was neglected, until I had stood waiting until past Midnight. There still remained there The Earl and Countess of Jersey, Lord and Lady Granville, and Sir James Macintosh, who sat round the fire in the Library conversing upon the Methodists, Foster’s Essays, the Church, the Athanasian Creed, and other miscellaneous subjects— Sir James Macintosh and Lady Granville had been this morning to Church, where Sir James said they had heard a mild and moderate Sermon; . . . But, said I by way of atonement for his moderation he gave you the Athanasian Creed. . . Sir James said yes—to be sure— . . . they had that.— Lord Holland said there were many Church Clergymen, who at their peril took it upon them to omit it omit reading it; and that the Duke of Grafton always got up and went out of Church, when it was begun to be read— Lady Jersey said she wished she could go to a Methodist chapel, without being known.— About half past twelve a Servant came, and told me that my Carriage was at the door; and on going down I found Mrs Adams had been waiting there ever since eleven— I had been all the same time waiting for the Carriage, and had thoughtlessly neglected to enquire of the Servants if it had come— It was too late to go to Countess Lieven’s, and we returned home; which we reached soon after one in the Morning.

3. VII:45. Besides the usual dissipation of Spirits after dining abroad and late hours of returning home, I had the additional languor this morning, of self dissatisfaction, with the day of yesterday. But as the best mediator of self reconciliation is employment, I wrote Letters, in answer to R. W. Fox junr. son of the Consul at Falmouth— To W. Couling; proposing to see him at my Office in Craven Street, the day after to-morrow—to a Mr Kellermann, who wrote me a letter from Copenhagen, proposing that the United States should purchase of the Danish Government the Nicobar Islands in the East-Indies— To Mr Edward Wyer, Consul at Riga; and to Mr Woolsey at Liverpool, informing him of the Note I received from Lord Castlereagh, respecting the American Brig William, and her Cargo. I also wrote something, but not enough in my Journal.— Walked an hour before dinner alone; and an hour after dinner with Mrs Adams.— Received by the Evening Post, letters from Mr Maury at Liverpool; from Mr Pitcairn at Edinburgh, a Card of Countess Jersey at Home, for this Evening; and a line from Mr J. A. Smith, saying that a message had just come, that the Countess of Jersey’s party for this Evening was put off.

4. VIII:30. Though I was not at London yesterday, nor up to a late hour last Night, I nevertheless rose very late this morning, and had an aversion to close occupation— After writing less than a page of my journal, I rode with Mrs Adams to the Queen’s Elms at Brompton, to deliver to Mr Salisbury, the seeds sent for him by Mr Sumter, from Rio de Janeiro— From the Queen’s Elms we were referred to Sloan Street, where we found Mr Salisbury and his house and nursery Garden; but he was himself not at home. I left the seeds, with my Card, and a Message, for Mr Salisbury, if he should wish to write to Mr Sumter, to send me his Letter— Returning home I walked from the third Milestone— Received by the Evening Post a Letter from Mr Lambert, enclosing one for Savannah. a Letter from Mr M’Call, Consul of Barcelona, and a Letter from Mr C. J. Hippisley, a young man who wishes to obtain a Commission, in the American Navy— He encloses Certificates of good conduct, during five years that he was in the British Navy— I had written to his father, in answer to an application from him to know whether he could obtain employment in the American Navy, that it would be certainly impossible, unless he could previously obtain the Prince Regent’s permission to enter the American Service. Upon which the young Man immediately wrote to the Lords of the Admiralty, asking that permission— He has sent me a copy of their answer; signed by John Barrow, their Under Secretary— It is, that he Hippisley, being no longer in the British Navy, that Department has nothing to do with the subject of his solicitation— Took half an hours walk with my wife after dinner— This was the king’s birth day; the chyming of Ealing Church Bells and several flags flying at the village Churches, were all the indications of it, that we saw.

5. VI. The arrears of my Journal are a continual pressure upon me. I shall probably be very soon compelled to change my plan, and to notice the Events of every day in the most summary manner, and in a very few lines. This morning I rose earlier than has of late been usual with me; but it brought me only to the 12th: of last Month— Soon after breakfast I went in to London— I had appointed to meet Mr Couling at my Office at three O’Clock— I returned him his Letter of proposals; and he engaged to furnish me with another next Saturday— There was a Mr Conan whom Mr Smith introduced to me, and who mentioned the accounts from America, of the Death of Mr S. Dexter of Boston. Received a Note from Lord Castlereagh enclosing a copy of an Order from the Lords of the Treasury to the Commissioners of the Customs, to repay all extra Tonnage duties, levied upon American Vessels— Three Letters from my Mother; one to George, and two to my wife. A Letter from Thomas Pride, a Land Surveyor and Draftsman in Monmouthshire; wanting to go to the United States—A pamphlet—the Account and Plan of the Society of Friends of Foreigners in Distress; sent by the Treasurer, Mr William Vaughan.— Mr J. A. Smith went with me to the City of London Tavern, in Bishopsgate Street, where we dined with this Society. The Duke of York was to have been in the Chair but sent an Apology of being engaged in business, and with the Prince Regent. The Duke of Kent brought his excuse, and presided in his stead— The Duke of Sussex was prevented from attending by illness— The Duke of Gloucester, by particular engagement— Prince Paul Esterhazy, Count Lieven, Mr Pfeffel, Baron Rehausen, Count Munster, and Baron Just, and Count Jenison, Walworth were there; with a company of about four hundred persons, Lord de Dunstanville, and Mr J. C. Villiers, brother of the Earl of Clarendon, were the principal personages of this Country, present— Lord Castlereagh—Mr Vansittart and some others sent excuses. Mr Dubachefsky and the Chevalier Seguier, the Russian and French Consuls were also there— I sat at table, between Lord de Dunstanville and Mr Dubatchefsky; whom I met at Countess Colombi’s at dinner in the Summer of 1813. and had not since seen. Mr S. G. Perkins of Boston was likewise of the Company. Mr Villiers recognized and spoke to me, having been present when I had my first Audience of the Queen— I had seen him before that, when we were presented to the ">king of France at the Thuileries, in February 1815. I did not then know him; nor his name until this day. He told me that Mrs Bagot, the wife of the British Minister in the United States was his niece, and I find that he married Mrs Wellesley-Pole’s Sister.— He spoke highly both of Mr and Mrs Bagot, and told me that they were much pleased with their reception in America. Count Lieven and Prince Esterhazy, before dinner hinted to the Duke of Kent, that if their Sovereigns should be toasted or themselves they could not make speeches— He said laughing that if they would tell him in three words what to say he would speak for them— But that I could speak English very fluently, and I must speak for them all— The hour appointed for the dinner was precisely half past five O’Clock, and the company actually sat down about six— The dinner was good, and the toasting began early— The king, in respectful silence— The Prince Regent, Protector, and the Queen, Protectress of the Society each as well as the following toasts with three times three— The Emperor of Russia, and the King of Prussia were drank successively as Protectors, the Duke of
Kent, introducing their healths with an appropriate eulogium, in each case, and especially reminding the company, of the urbanity and affability displayed by those Sovereigns when they dined with the Society at their anniversary two years ago. The Duke also returned the thanks of Count Lieven for the toast; and also for the Prussian Minister, when the king was toasted. Baron Jacobi was not present— The next toast was the Emperor of Austria; upon which the Duke, for Prince Esterhazy, addressed the Company; assuring them that although the Emperor was not yet one of the Protectors of the Society, it was only because he had been prevented from executing his intention of coming to this Country with the other Sovereigns two years ago. But that he the Prince should write an account of this meeting, and had no doubt he should receive authority to subscribe for the Emperor as one of the Protectors— The Duke next toasted his royal Sisters, the Princesses, patronesses of the Society; with an apology for his egotism, and an affectionate panegyric upon the benevolence of their dispositions.— The Princess Charlotte and the Prince of Coburg were drank, with the same marks of enthusiasm in her favour which I have witnessed on many late occasions.— The Duke of Kent’s own health was then proposed by Lord de Dunstanville, one of the Vice Presidents and Stewards of the day, who introduced it with some complimentary remarks— The Duke returned thanks, with assurance, of his attachment to the Society and its objects, and with allusions to his intention of shortly leaving the Country for some years. The Duke of York and the Army, the Duke of Clarence and the Navy; and the Duke of Gloucester, the first Patron of the Society were toasted successively; after which the Duke of Kent gave, the Foreign Ambassadors and Ministers present, prefacing it with remarks upon his personal satisfaction, at seeing so large a number of them, Ministers of Peace, from Countries with whom this Nation but a few years since, had unfortunate differences— The Hall he said in this respect, exhibited a contrast, most auspicious to this Country to the aspect which it would have had, only four years since— The Duke then, with the assent and request of all the Ambassadors present, called upon me to answer the toast; which I did nearly to this effect—“Gentlemen,—Deeply sensible as I am, to the honour done me, by my illustrious and excellent colleagues, in calling upon me to make our common acknowledgments for that which you have done us in the toast just given by His Royal Highness from the Chair, I feel myself no less at a loss for words than they can be, suitably to make this return for your goodness to them and to me— For although I am indebted for this distinguished charge, to the accidental advantage of speaking the same language as most of you; yet I must intreat your indulgence when I say that expressions suitable to convey the sense of their gratitude and mine, are at this moment as little at my command as at their’s. If, Gentlemen, it were the highest honour of this Institution, that it has for its Protectress, Her Majesty, the Queen Consort of this Realm, a Princess, who throughout life, has been by her private and domestic virtues, a model for her sex, as by her civic virtues she is an ornament to her exalted station— That it has for its Protectors, His Royal Highness the Prince Regent, the acting Sovereign of this Great Empire; and joined with him, a second Alexander, more glorious than the first—glorious, not by the conquest of the Earth, but by saving the Earth from Conquest; and a Frederick-William, glorious by having redeemed his kingdom and his Country, as by fire, entire and unimpaired, from the furnace of adversity— That to these, you have had this day, the promised expectation of shortly adding the name of their brother in arms and in virtue; His Majesty the Emperor of Austria.— That among the names of your Patrons and Patronesses, you reckon those of many Princes and Princesses, of the most resplendent lines in Europe— That you have the happiness of seeing in that Chair, a Prince of the illustrious House of Brunswick, to whose personal character beneficence is so congenial, that wherever it forms the basis of association, there, he seems naturally called to preside— If, I say, Gentlemen, these were your highest honours, well might my honourable Colleagues, well at least might I find my powers of language exhausted, in attempting to convey to you the sentiments which would animate us, in hearing our names thus associated with such great and glorious names— But, Gentlemen, these are not your highest honours— Proud as you have reason to be of these high distinctions, your highest honour in my estimation, and I will presume to say in that of those noble persons who have permitted me to address you in their names, is the principle of your association— That principle which has connected all those great and glorious names with your Society, and with your exertions.— Gentlemen, the sublime language of your immortal Poet, who asked a Kingdom for a Stage, Princes to act, and Monarchs to behold the swelling Scene, is not large enough for the purposes of your Institution— Your Theatre, is not a single kingdom, but the whole habitable globe— Your Actors are Princes and Monarchs—and the beholders; are the blessed Spirits that encircle the throne of Omnipotence— They look down on labours like these with complacency—they behold, the swelling
Scene with delight— For the Action, the object of your labours is the first, and noblest of moral and Christian virtues—Charity— Charity in its most extensive sense— Charity, not confined to one language, one religion or one Country, but expansive as the Globe, and universal as the blessings of Providence. Gentlemen, to give utterance to the feelings which fill the bosoms of my noble colleagues, and my own, in return for the notice bestowed upon us by such an Association, is beyond the powers of language possessed by us all. We can only say in the honesty and simplicity of our hearts, we thank you.”— This address was very well received— Lord de Dunstanville, Mr Villiers, and the Russian and French Consuls, complimented me civilly upon it. Mr Villiers asked me if I had been prepared for it.— I told him I had not had a conception until the moment when we sat down to dinner, that I should be called upon to answer for the whole Corps Diplomatique— But the truth is, I was not gifted by nature with the talent of extemporaneous speaking; and on this and all the other similar occasions, I have felt myself in much embarrassment, and have got through without discredit, only by revolving during the dinner time, what to say; a process not remarkably favourable to the enjoyment of the conviviality of the table— My aukwardness was this day aggravated, by an observation of a Gentleman, who sat opposite to me at the table, that he had heard at one of these same dinners, some years ago, a Speech from Mr Pinkney which he should never forget, and of which he spoke in an extasy of admiration— I confess the eulogy might have come at a more acceptable moment— But this Table-Cloth Oratory, is one of the duties of an American Minister in this Country, which I had not anticipated— The Vice Presidents of the Society were toasted next, for which their thanks were returned in a short Speech by Lord de Dunstanville. Mr Charles Murray the Secretary read an account of the proceedings of the Society, and the donations and subscriptions of this day, amounting to upwards of £700— Mr Vaughan the Treasurer was toasted, and returned thanks, in so low a voice that although near him at table, I could not hear him.— The Stewards of the day were given, and Lord de Dunstanville returned thanks for them.— Then the foreign Clergyman, the founders of the Society, for whom Mr Schwabe returned thanks in good language, but with a German accent— Another foreign Clergyman, a Mr Kuper, was also toasted, and thanked— Lastly the Duke of Kent, gave, the Directors of the Society, and observed that as it was growing late, he would join in the toast, the Secretary Mr Murray.— He returned thanks for them all.— The Duke of Kent’s Band of Music attended, and performed during and after the dinner— Non Nobis was sung after dinner— This is a gloomy piece of Church-Music, which at almost all these Public Dinners they sing, instead of a Grace after meat. They had also besides the usual National Songs, God Save the king, and Rule Britannia; several others; grave and gay. About half past ten the Duke of Kent left the Chair; and was followed, by the persons of the Centre Table— I sat down Mr Smith at Craven Street, and got home between twelve and one— Mr Pfeffel told me that a new Minister from Wurtemberg, General Neiffer had arrived, and that Count Baroldingen was recalled— Mr Perkins spoke of the late accounts from America, as being full of commercial distress, and threatening many failures—which he attributes to the process of getting the new Bank of the United States into Operation.— He thinks of sailing next week with Mrs Perkins for Boston.

6. VII:30. Having brought this book out last Evening from London, I began the Journal for this Month; leaving the arrears of the last, from the 12th: to the close, to be brought up, as I may find time.— Began also a Letter to my Mother, to be sent by Mr Perkins. Mrs Adams and George went to London, and returned home, between seven and eight O’Clock to dinner. John and Charles also dined at home, and had two of their schoolmates Franklin and Chapman to dine with them— They were all obliged to leave the table early, to return to school in time for the hour prescribed by Dr Nicholas which is half past eight. I walked before dinner to Hanwell Common, and across the fields to Ealing.— Received John’s Letter from School; announcing the vacation to commence the 21st. of this Month, for six week; and inviting us to the Play to be performed on the 12th. 13th. and 14th. John urged me strongly to give them leave to come home the 15th.—upon which I postponed giving a definitive Answer.

7. VI. Mr Renwick had requested me to write him a Letter, testifying to the respectable character of the house of Reid, Irving and Co. I made enquiry accordingly— Mr Vaughan informed me that it was a house of very respectable character, doing much business: I wrote the Letter this morning to Mr Renwick, and enclosed it to Mr Smith, to be forwarded to him at Liverpool; where he is gone to embark for the United States— Wrote a Letter to Mr C. J. Hippisley, in answer to that received from him; and finished the letter to my Mother— The journal engrosses all my daily leisure— Walk alone before dinner—and after dinner with Mrs Adams. Received by the Evening Post, Letters from Mr Reuben Shapley of Portsmouth New Hampshire—A Duplicate, concerning a claim that he has upon the British Government—a Duplicate— From Mr John Jacob Astor at New-York, in reply to one from me of 3. March. From G. M. Woolsey at Liverpool, answering mine to him of the 3d. and from a woman named Maria Cavendish, enclosing
one addressed to H. Clay Esqr Washington City which she requests me to forward. George supped this Evening at Dr Nicholas’s, with two of his Schoolmates, Thresher and Newman, who are leaving it, at the close of the present term.

8. VI:30. Employed the Morning before breakfast upon my Journal. Went to London alone— Returned Lord Erskine’s visit; to thank him for his Speech on the Orders in Council, but he was not at home. I then called upon Coll Sarrazin de Maraise, who brought a Letter of Introduction from Mr Boyd at Paris, to Mrs: Adams.— Stopp’d at Silvester, the engraver’s shop in the Strand, with Bode’s Uranographia, for him to take the design of a device for a seal from the Constellation of Lyra. At the Office in Craven-Street, I found a Mr Kennedy; an American, whom Mr Smith introduced to me— There were Letters from—Mr Herman Visger at Bristol, informing me that he has received a Commission as Consul of the United States at that Port, and enquiring what measures he is to take to obtain his exequatur, and to execute his official Bond— From Mr G. W. Erving, at Paris, two— From Mr Couling, containing his final proposal of terms upon which he would go to America to be employed as a civil Engineer, by the Governor of Virginia; and with it a large packet of Plans, Drawings and Designs, by him, to be sent out as specimens of his talents, and competency for the business— From Barrett Ames, and his friends Ogden, Richards and Selden, requesting me to procure for him a permission from the Alien Office to embark at Liverpool, where he is for America— From Mr Gallatin at New-York—3. Feby: recommending Mr John Cook, a Chaplain in the army of the United States, who comes to Europe, on a furlough, for a year— Mr Cook left the Letter at the Office yesterday with his card. Mr Gallatin says in his Letter that he believes he will embark with his family, for France, the beginning of May.— From the two Mates of the ship Baltimore—Kenrick apologising awkwardly, for having signed his name to their former joint Letter, together with the other, who signed by the name of James Brown, though his real name is George Dutton—and Dutton himself, still signing his name James Brown—persisting in the pretence that it is his real name, and stating that he has given his protection to Mr Fox, to send to me, in proof of it— I wrote a Note to Charles Lullin, who was first Clerk at the Alien Office, enquiring whether it be now necessary for foreigners to have permissions from that Office to leave the Kingdom; and if it be, asking one for Barrett Ames.— Mr Smith went between four and five, to dine with Mr Murdoch— On my return home I walked from the 4th. Milestone 57 minutes— At home I found a Note from Lord Holland, enquiring if I could furnish him with any accurate statements of the amount of expenditure of the civil list in the United States— I saw by the Newspapers that in the House of Lords last Evening the Earl of Liverpool asserted that the expences of the civil list in America, amounted to nearly as much as in this country—to about 800,000 pounds Sterling. I dictated an answer to Lord Holland’s Letter, which my wife wrote and copied.

9. VII. Answered the Letter of Thomas Pride, the Land-surveyor, who wishes to go to America. Sent the footman William to Holland house, with my answer to Lord Holland’s Letter, the Estimates of Appropriations, by the Secretary of the Treasury for the present year; another Public Document, shewing the whole expenditures of the Government of the United States, from the establishment of the present Constitution to 4. March 1815. Twenty-six Years: and Spafford’s Gazetteer of New-York, which contains a statement of the annual expenditure of the Government of that State— Answered the Letter from Herman Visger at Bristol. Attended Church— Mr Carr read Prayers for Trinity Sunday, including the Athanasian Creed. Dr: Nicholas preached the Sermon from Matthew XXVIII:19. Go ye therefore, and teach all Nations, baptizing them in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost.— The Discourse was in support of the Doctrine of the Trinity; but contained nothing new: and the argument with regard to the third person was weak— After Church we had a visit from Mr and Mrs Delafield, who stopped on their return to London from an excursion of a fortnight into the Country. Mr Delafield said they had heard great and bitter complaints of the distresses of the times. Saw great numbers of poor People unemployed, sauntering about the Streets and at ale-houses, in idleness—and were told at one place, that the wages of labourers were only one shilling and six pence a week; which the Parish were obliged to make up eight shillings— I wrote the Draft of a Note to Lord Castlereagh concerning the case of the Brig Nanina— Short walk to Brentford before dinner. John Newman, Thresher and Burningham, three of George’s Schoolmates, who are to leave the School, at the end of the term, dined with us— Sheaffe was likewise invited, but could not come; being deeply engaged in learning the part of Pamphilus in Terence’s Andria, which is to be performed this week at the school— The part was to have been played by another
boy, or rather young Man named Russell, who had learnt, and rehearsed it several times— But three days ago, he quarreled, and fought with a schoolmate, and was sent home blind. The part was then given to Sheaffe, on so short a notice that he can spare no time to go out.— We walked with the boys back to school, after dinner.— There was this Night a total eclipse of the Moon, which I saw, untill the Moon was totally covered— It began at half past eleven, and was total at a quarter past one. I sat up till within a quarter of two—but the atmosphere had clouded up so that the issuing of the Moon from the eclipse could not be seen— I did not wait for it.

10. VII:30. Wrote to G. W. Erving at Paris, and enclosed the Letter under cover to Messrs: Hottinguer and Co.— The Note to Lord Castlereagh on the case of the Nanina, with which I enclosed the Documents, left at my Office by Mr Walker, of the House of Greg Lindsay and Co. Correspondents and Agents of John B. Murray and Son of New-York, owners of the Nanina— Half a page of Journal— Received this morning a Note from Mr Capper of the Alien Office, in answer to that which I had written to Mr Lullin, formerly the chief Clerk— Mr Capper informs me that Mr Lullin has left the Office and retired to Switzerland— That no permission is now necessary from the Alien-Office to enable Aliens to embark at the different Ports—and that as soon, as the new Alien-Act now before Parliament shall have passed he will send me a copy of it.— Also a Letter from A. Glennie and Son, respecting the wages of the Seamen of the Baltimore—requesting me to appoint a time to meet one of them upon the subject— Mr Smith undertook when he went into the City on Saturday to give them, and also Coll Aspinwall and Mr Fox of Falmouth notice that I wished to meet them at my Office to-morrow on this business— Dr Nicholas’s daughters, Caroline and Laura paid with a Miss Armstrong a visit to Mrs Adams While we were at dinner, I received a Card, of the Countess of Jersey at Home this Evening— I went to the party, and arriving at 11 O’Clock, found a very small part of the Company assembled.— The only person whom I at first knew there, was the Marquis of Lansdowne. afterwards, there came the Russian, Spanish and Dutch Ambassadors, Prince and Princess Esterhazy—Countess Lieven, Count Beroldingen Mr Pfeffel, Mr Neumann, Prince Esterhazy the father, Lady Castlereagh, Mrs Villiers, the Earl of Lonsdale, Lord Erskine, Captain d’Este, Son of the Duke of Sussex, the Prince of Coburg’s Gentleman Baron Hardenbroek, the two Count’s Bentheim, and many others—perhaps three hundred persons—among the rest was a young Lady, of remarkable appearance, whom I found upon enquiry to be a daughter of Lord Edward Fitzgerald, and of Mrs Pitcairn— Whether the one I had seen at Hamburg, as a child, or another, I could not ascertain— The two Young Frenchwomen, whom I had met at the Duke de la Chatre’s, with their father were there, and performed on the Piano, and sung several Songs, indifferently but much to the extasy of some of the Ladies. I came away about one of the morning: the company was then fast thinning off, and most of them were going to a Ball at Mrs Fitzherberts. It was about half past two when I reached home, and nearly broad day-light.

11. VIII:30. It was in vain to think of writing this morning; though I made a feeble and fruitless attempt upon this Journal. I was obliged almost immediately after Breakfast, to go to London. There I found at the Office Mr Leslie, a young American Painter, who lives with Mr Alston— He has painted a family picture of Mr King’s three Children— Has a picture of some reputation, at the present exhibition, at Somerset house; and is patronized by the President of the Academy Mr West— I had a visit from Mr John Cook, the Chaplain in the army, recommended to me by Mr Gallatin— He is an Irishman; but has been upwards of twenty years residing in America, and now obtained a leave of absence for a year, to come and look up some of his family relations; most of them are dead, and he has been unsuccessful, particularly in the search for his Son, of whom he can obtain no tidings.— He told me he had a friend at New-York, named Thomas Story; also an Irishman, and one of those who nearly twenty years since was proscribed by name, for the part which they then took in the troubles of Ireland— Mr Story wishes to obtain a permission to go to Ireland for a few Months, to settle some private affairs there, and then return to America— And Mr Cook enquired if I could interpose with the British Government to obtain such a permission. I assured him that I readily would, if I could do it with any prospect of success— But I intimated to him the great delicacy of the subject, and the belief that unless there was a probability that the application would succeed, it would be from many considerations advisable not to make it— Mr Cook likewise wanted a small sum of money, about one hundred dollars, for his personal expences, for which he offered his own Bill of Exchange, upon the same Mr Thomas Storey; and I agreed to supply him and take his bill— While he was with me, Coll Aspinwall, Mr Fox of Falmouth and Mr James S. Glennie came in, with Captain Wrothbond Baker, the Master of the Ship Baltimore, which he abandoned at Sea, and which has already occasioned me much trouble and vexation. I shewed him the note from Messrs. William and James Brown of Liverpool, addressed to him, recommending Mr Dutton to him for a mate, and which the Steward of the ship, Gustavus M. Ware had given me. He declared and persisted in the Declaration that he had never seen the note before. I shewed him the Protection in the name of James Brown, which Dutton gave to R. W. Fox junr. to send to me, as his proof that his name was James Brown, and that he was an American Citizen— Baker said that that Protection, was an old one,
which with four or five others, belonging to Sailors who had been with him on former voyages, had remained in his possession; and all of which he had left locked up in the lid of his chest at Falmouth— I asked him if he did or did not know that the real name of the pretended James Brown, was George Dutton— He equivocated, but said he had heard him called by the name of Dutton.— Said he had always told him his name was James Brown, and had been recommended to him by that name by Captain Abrams, Master of the American Ship Adriana of Baltimore— I shewed Mr Glennie the note from W. & J. Brown of Liverpool, which he recognized as their hand-writing— I then requested him to write to those Gentlemen, stating these circumstances to them; asking an explanation of them, and informing them that I expected a candid answer— With regard to the wages of the Seamen, there was much discussion, but nothing agreed to— Baker had produced an account against the Seamen, to part of which they had objected. He told one Story, and they another. It was finally agreed, that they should all meet to-morrow at Coll. Aspinwall’s Office, where Mr Fox, and Mr Glennie would also attend; where both parties should be heard in presence of each other, and the attempt would be made to come to some agreement— Baker said he was going away— Going to embark for America, and asked me for a Passport. I told him I could give him none until he gave his Seamen their discharge and settled with them for their wages. It was near five O’Clock when they left my Office— Mr G. Joy came in a few minutes before, and went away with Coll: Aspinwall— I had received this morning before I left home, the Letter from R. W. Fox junr: enclosing the Protection in the name of Brown, in which the description of the person had been recently altered by erasure and new writing; and also a Letter from Coll Aspinwall, in reply to the last which I wrote him— At the Office I found—a Note from Baron Jacobi Kloest, the Prussian Minister, informing me that a Mr am Ende, a Merchant at New-Orleans has been appointed Prussian Consul there, enclosing a Packet for him, containing his Commission, to be forwarded, and requesting me to give notice of the appointment to the Government of the United States, and to solicit the exequatur— A note from Mr M. C. Paterson, announcing his intention of going in a few days to the continent; and requesting Letters of Introduction to American Public Officers, in Holland, France and Italy.— A Letter from the Chevalier de Llano at Berlin; very long, and enclosing an exposé, not more concise of the Literary works which he is projecting, and for which he wants Printers and Translators & Booksellers.— And a Letter from Messrs: Belles and Harrold, of Birmingham requesting me to obtain a permission from the British Government, to export Rollers for the use of the Mint of the United States, and enclosing an extract of a Letter to them from Mr Patterson the Director of the Mint— Some of these Letters, I read in the Carriage, while returning home— I could walk only from Kew-Bridge home. Letter from our Son Charles to his Mother, announcing the approaching vacation at school.

12. VII. Besides the Journal to which every disposable moment is devoted, I answered the note yesterday received from Baron Jacobi-Kloest— The Letters of Belles and Harrold concerning the permission to export Rollers, of Barrett Ames, asking for a permission from the Alien-Office to embark at Liverpool, of a Mr M’Lellan at Hamilton, Scotland; a letter I have had upon file, about a month—and wrote a Letter of Introduction for Mr M. C. Paterson, to Mr Gallatin— The same Letter was copied by Mrs Adams, and addressed to Mr Eustis, Mr W. Pinkney, Mr H. Jackson, and Mr A. H. Everett. Walk to Hanwell Common, and across the fields to Ealing— By the Evening Post I received a Letter from Mr James S. Glennie— He has written to W. and J. Brown, at Liverpool, requesting one of them to come to London, and explain the affair of the first Mate of the ship Baltimore— This was the first Evening of the performance of Terence’s Andria, at Dr Nicholas’s school. We had intended to go, only at the third and last night; but while at dinner, we concluded to go this Evening— The performance began at eight, and finished before eleven— George had the part of Crito— The whole performance did not quite equal my expectations.

13. VII. Answered Mr James S. Glennie’s Note, received last Evening. Received Letters—from Coll: Aspinwall, who says that Captain Baker evaded attending at the meeting which had been agreed upon at my Office; and therefore no arrangement could be made relative to the wages of the Seamen of the ship Baltimore— I had a visit from Mr Hamilton, from Philadelphia, who informed me that he now resided with his Aunt, Mrs Franks, at Isleworth— Mrs Von Harten came from Clapham where she now has lodgings, and passed the day with Mrs Adams, and dined with us.— She is in great distress, and appears to be almost in the last Stage of a Consumption— Her husband has been upwards of two Months in the King’s Bench Prison, and is going through a Commission
of Bankruptcy— She expected he would be released this day. Their house at Drayton-Green has been seized and sold. She was obliged to go at first into lodgings in the City; but found her illness so much increased there that she was again compelled to remove into the Country, and took Apartments at Clapham. She told Mrs Adams this day the whole History of her life, which has been very unhappy, by the misconduct of her former husband— It is now embittered by Von Harten’s misfortunes, and she is so much reduced that a very short time, will in every probability bring both her sorrows and her joys in this world to a close.— She left us immediately after dinner, to return home— I was employed part of this day, in hearing George recite his part in the Play— We dined at five; and in the Evening I went again to see the performance— Met Mrs Elmsley there, with her daughters— The whole performance was much better than last Evening.

14. VII:30. Answered Mr T. Wilson’s Letter which I received yesterday respecting a claim of Reuben Shapley of Portsmouth, New Hampshire; against the British Government—and wrote to Governor Nicholas of Virginia, to enclose W. Couling’s proposals. At one O’Clock, we went to Dr Nicholas’s school to hear the Declamations of the boys— The Duke of Kent, had promised to attend this day; but sent an apology, saying that the Duke of Orleans was to come and dine with him at four O’Clock.— The Speeches were in Greek, Latin, French and English.— Our Sons George and Charles both spoke in French—Charles, a Fable, composed for the occasion, by Mr Ledieu the French Teacher, and George, the Death of Coligny from Voltaire’s Henriade— On returning home from the Speeches we found Mr Joy who had promised to come out and attend them, but was too late— George’s Schoolmate Chambre dined with him at four— Mr Joy dined with us; and in the Evening we attended the performance of the Andria; the third and last time. It was much better than either of the former Nights; and on the whole very well— The Prologue and Epilogue were spoken twice— The Hall was quite crowded with company— Our Sons all came home from School this Evening, for the vacation— Mr Joy lodged at our house— I received this morning a Letter from Mr: Grubb, with a proposal from Mr Matheson, who has a new system of teaching, and wishes to bring out to my house, half a dozen of his scholars to explain it to me, and exhibit before me.— One from Herman Visger at Bristol, enclosing his Commission as American Consul at that Port, for the Exequatur— And one from J. M. Forbes, at New-York; recommending a kinsman of his—Dr Murray. He left the Letter at Craven Street.

15. VII: Immediately after Breakfast, I went with Mr Joy to London— I found at the Office, Gustavus M. Ware, the Steward of the ship Baltimore, who repeated again the circumstances which he had related before, concerning the abandonment of that ship, at sea, and concerning the first mate, shipped at Liverpool. There was a Gentleman, who came from a person at Canterbury, to ask me to certify upon a paper Authenticated by the Mayor of that City, the signature of the Mayor, and that he held that Office. It being a document relating to an Estate in Georgia.— I promised to give the Certificate, upon the evidence being produced to me. Letters—from Lord Holland, returning the Documents and Book that I had lent him— From Mr G. A. Thompson who has published a Dictionary of America, and the West-Indies, including a Translation of the Spanish work of Alcedo, and to which he requests my name, as a subscriber. It is in five Quarto Volumes, of which he sends me one to examine— It contains the Article “United States,” and Mr Thompson professes to have drawn it up with impartiality; more than I could discover upon inspecting it— So large a work however must contain much useful information; and it is compiled in the convenient form of a Dictionary. I propose therefore to subscribe for it.— From Barrett Ames at Liverpool—a second Letter for a Passport from the Alien-Office, before he had received my answer to the first— An Invitation from Countess Lieven to her Evening party to-morrow. I left Mr Visger’s Commission with Mr Smith to be taken to the foreign Office, in Downing Street— Returning home, I walked from Kew-Bridge.— Mrs Chambré, the Mother of George’s schoolfellow, and his elder brother paid Mrs Adams a visit while I was in town.— Ellen Nicholas was also here, part of the morning.

16. VII:15. Attended Church with the three boys— Prayers for the first Sunday after Trinity having been read by Mr Millman, who was ordained a Priest at Oxford last Sunday, and therefore read the absolution with the rest of the Service, the Sermon was preached by Mr Moses Bankes—from Isaiah LVIII.7. “Is it not to deal thy bread to the hungry, and that thou bring the poor that are cast out to thy house? when thou seest the naked that thou cover him; and that thou hide not thyself from thine own flesh.” It was a Charity Sermon, for the benefit of the Sunday Schools and School of Industry in Old Brentford, and was not different from most other Charity Sermons— The Duke of Kent’s Band attended, and performed several pieces of music— The Collection was made after Church, and the Plates were held, by Mr Carr the vicar and his daughter, and by Dr Nicholas and his daughter Caroline— George’s Schoolmates Thresher and Sheaffe dined with us— They are about finally leaving the school; and after dinner took leave of George, who was much affected with it— I went with Mrs Adams to Countess Lieven’s Evening party, which was not much crowded. Baron Fagel invited us to an Evening party at his house the day after to-morrow. Prince Esterhazy the Austrian Ambassador, presented me to his Princess; she was a daughter of the Princess of La Tour et Taxis, who was a
Sister of the late Queen of Prussia, and of the present Duchess of Cumberland.— The Earl of Limerick introduced me to Lord Binning. I enquired of Mr Neumann, the Secretary of the Austrian Embassy, whether small arms, as well as ships, and Cannon were to be procured by purchase from his Government? He said he thought they were, and he promised to write, and enquire; and of their prices. Curtoys, the Secretary of the Spanish Embassy told me, that he knew not when he should return to Spain— The Ambassador, Count Fernan-Nuñez had told me that his own brother was coming to take the place of Curtoys— But Curtoys said he did not know how that would be— It was an elder, and illegitimate brother of the Count’s who was to come; and it was quite uncertain whether he would come, or not— Curtoys told Mrs Adams, that he was so disgusted with the trifling nonsens which was all they had to do here, that he was excessively anxious to be gone— Mr Balk Oleff the Russian Minister going to Rio de Janeiro told me that he should embark, about the beginning of the next Month, in a British ship of the line, going to India, but which this Government had directed to land him in Brazil.— Lord and Lady Castlereagh were at this party—and Lord and Lady Hampden, Lord Westmorland, Sir Henry Wellesley &c— We left the party before supper, and reached home, at half past two in the Morning— By day light.

17. VIII:30. I wrote last Evening to Mr James S. Glennie, in answer to a Letter I had received the day before from him. He had informed me that Mr. James Brown, of the house at Liverpool had arrived in London, and they wished me to appoint a time when I would see them— I appointed this day 3. O’Clock at Craven Street— Immediately after Breakfast I walked from home about four miles; when I overtook the Hammersmith Stage in which, I went into London— Alighted at the king’s mews near Leicester Square. Went to the Covent Garden Theatre Box-Office to bespeak tickets, for the 28th. Miss S. Booth’s benefit, when Shakespear’s As you like it is to be performed; but the Box keeper told me she had not informed him what boxes she had reserved to let herself, and what he might dispose of— He should know to-morrow.— At Drury Lane Theatre, I took two seats for this Evening— At the Office in Craven-Street, Mr James S. Glennie came with Mr Brown of Liverpool. Brown admitted that the note to Captain Baker, recommending Dutton to him as a Mate was written by a partner of the house, and he had no doubt had been received at the time, by Baker— He said that Dutton had been recommended to them by Captain Budd, who had been a Lieutenant in the Navy of the United States, but lastly Captain of a vessel called the Acme of Baltimore, seized and condemned last Winter, in Ireland, for smuggling.— Budd had told them that Dutton had been Mate on board the Acme— He added that since Dutton had been at Falmouth, they, the Brown’s had written to him, offering him the place of Mate on board the Eagle, a vessel they were sending out to India, but he had declined accepting the offer— Dutton’s own Story to R. W. Fox junr. was that he had been mate of the Adriana, a Baltimore vessel which foundered at sea last winter, and the crew of which were taken out of her by a British vessel, called the St Patrick— But Ware, the Steward of the Baltimore says that Dutton, was the mate of the St. Patrick; an Englishman, and had never been in the United States— Mr Brown thanked me for having obtained the order to the Collector at Liverpool, to clear out American Vessels for Batavia— But he declined paying any part of the wages of the Seamen of the Baltimore. He said they had already advanced upon the ship, more money than she was worth, and the owner was not a responsible person. Immediately after these persons left the office, Mr Cook came in— I paid him the remainder of £22:10. and took his Bill upon New-York for one hundred dollars— I had afterwards a visit from Mr Allston and Mr Leslie, the Painters—and a note from Mr Ingraham, enclosing a pamphlet from Washington, respecting the Presidential Election, and requesting me to examine his accounts, and sent him a draft for the money.— Mr Smith went out to dinner— At 6. O’Clock, Mrs Adams came in the Carriage to town, and we went to Drury-Lane Theatre.— The Play was A new way to pay old debts, a revival from Massinger— Kean, in the part of Sir Giles Overreach.— Kean is now the most popular actor upon the London stage, and has had great success in this particular part— It was the 25th. time of his performing it this Season. I think him a good actor, but the Play itself a very miserable one, and Sir Giles Overreach, rant from beginning to end.— The Entertainments were, first a new farce, called The man his own Master; a translation from le Nouveau Seigneur de Village, leaving out the music—and secondly, the Irishman in London— We came away in the midst of the second act of this last piece; and after calling at Craven Street, where we found Mr Smith reading in bed, we went to the Marchioness dowager of Lansdowne’s Route— There the crowd
of fashionables was excessive—nearly five hundred persons crowded into two small chambers. As we entered the first Drawing-Room, we had the Duke of Cumberland immediately before us, and the Prince Regent immediately afterwards came up behind— It was not without difficulty that I made way for him to pass. We stayed there a full hour, jamm’d up in a corner of the Drawing-Room, and unable equally to advance or to retire. very few of the company were known to us— It was half past one in the morning when we got away, and as we descended the stairs we met Mr Forbes our old St: Petersburg acquaintance going up. He had just come from a similar party at the Countess of Jersey’s. About three O’Clock, almost at Sunrise we reached home; and after taking a very light substitute for my dinner, which I had omitted, at nearly four I retired to bed.

18. IX:15. The struggle to apply some part of the day to occupation becomes more laborious and painful, as the dissipations of the Season multiply— I inspected and examined Mr Ingraham’s accounts, and answered his Letter, enclosing a draft upon the Brothers Baring, for the amount of his advances. Mr Smith had sent me out yesterday two Letters, which I received on returning home this morning. One was for Mr. F. H. Ingersoll, addressed to my care— A Ship-Letter from Liverpool, and doubtless an answer from Mr Jared Ingersoll of Philadelphia, to the Letter from this person, which I transmitted to him last Summer. I enclosed this Letter to Mr: F. H. Ingersoll, at Chelsea— The other was from an American at Liverpool named Clisby; asking for a Passport; but without enclosing any documents. I answered, directing him to apply to the Consul at Liverpool, Mr Maury. I also wrote as much as I was able at my Journal. While at dinner I received Letters from my Father and Mother; and from Belles and Harrold at Birmingham.— After dinner I read with George, two Scenes of Terence’s Phormio— At ten Mrs Adams and I went into London, to an Evening party at the Dutch Ambassador Baron Fagel’s— It was rather late—there had been a party there at dinner, and it was a sort of celebration of the Battle of Waterloo, of which this is the anniversary. Some of the company were gone, but others were coming.— The Duchess of Wellington, and the Duke’s mother, Lady Mornington were there—Lord and Lady Castlereagh—Mr Wellesley-Pole—Mrs Villiers, Lord Fitzroy Somerset, and his Lady. Mr and Mrs Hamilton, the Spanish Ambassador, and the Sardinian and Saxon Ministers. Count Beroldingen took leave of me, and told me he should leave London, the day after to-morrow— Lord Castlereagh told me that Brougham had been asking this day in the House of Commons, for the papers of Lord Exmouth’s proceedings with the Barbary powers; but he had answered that he was not yet quite ready to give them.— He also said there had been this day a sort of confirmation of the Story which has been for some days in circulation, that there had been some subsequent hostilities by the Algerines against the British at Oran— I told him that I hoped it would tend to recommend the advice which I had taken the liberty to give him, and to persuade the British Government to put down the crying scandal of those Barbary Piracies— He intimated that the new quarrel was owing to an attempt of Lord Exmouth to obtain from the Dey of Algiers, a declaration that he would in future make no more Christian Slaves; similar to the Declarations which had been given by the Bey of Tunis and the Bashaw of Tripoli: and added that it could not be on account of the mere protest which Lord Exmouth was to make on his return to Algiers, against one Article of the Algerine Treaty with the United-States, because, he was not even to ask that the Treaty should be annulled; but only that the prior engagements with Great-Britain should not be broken— But Mr Hamilton, the Under-Secretary of State told me that they had this day received advices that the late quarrel between Lord Exmouth and the Algerines had been arranged; and that the vessels and the Vice-Consul, seized at Oran had been restored. I spoke to the Sardinian Minister, about the Peace made for Sardinia by Lord Exmouth, and found that he was content to consider it as a very advantageous one— He said to be sure they had some money to pay; but that was a trifle, and they had got all their prisoners ransomed; besides a stipulation by the Bey of Tunis, not to make any more Christian Slaves. We came away at half past twelve; and as we were descending the Stairs, met the Marquis of Camden, the Earl of Lonsdale, Viscount Sidmouth, and the two Miss Addington’s his daughters going up. The Earl of Westmorland immediately followed them. It was about two when we got home.

19. X— After being out three Nights successively, until morning broad daylight, I find a great want of repose— I wrote this day with extreme difficulty and no small pain.— I was compelled to take first a walk of half an hour with Mrs Adams, round our Garden— Then a walk alone, to Brentford and Ealing, and after dinner a walk again with Mrs Adams, and our three Sons, to the Boston Terrace at Brentford.— Finished reading with George, the first Act of Terence’s Phormio.— While we were at dinner, the Evening Post, brought a large budget of Letters— They were,—from my father, mother, brother and his wife, to Mrs Adams, each of the three boys, and myself— The latest date is of 27. May.— The Letters of my father and mother to me, relate chiefly to the Death of Mr S. Dexter of Boston— My brother’s Letter is about my affairs— He informs me that Mr Frederick Pursh, the man recommended to me last winter by Sir Joseph Banks, and to whom I lent the several sums of money, upon his promissory notes which he
assured me he would repay immediately upon his arrival in America, instead of repayment, drew a bill for 361 dollars, upon my brother, under the pretence of having funds in my hands, and then ran away to Montreal— The other Letters were from Mr Shaler, our Consul at Algiers, of 21. May, with an Account of Lord Exmouth’s proceedings on his second visit there— The threatened quarrel, and the final arrangement, by which hostilities were averted— Altogether a strange, and very unaccountable Story— From a Mr Corbin de la Beaussonniere a Frenchman, asking to see me, and from the Abbe Humblet, a sturdy beggar, who has already teazed me with his impertinence— From a Mr M’Bride at Dublin, still about the discrimination between the numbers of Passengers, allowed to be carried from Ireland, in British, and in American Vessels— From Mr. R. W. Fox, at London— From Mr G. Joy—and from Mr Charles King, and Mrs King, at Paris, to Mrs Adams.

20. VII. I redeemed the arrears of my Journal since the commencement of the present Month; and write this on the day itself; there still remains however, an arrear from the twelfth of May, to the close of that Month; to conclude the last Volume— We dined with Mr William Vaughan and his two Sisters at East-Hill, Wandsworth. Mr Belshape and his Sister, a Mr: and Mrs Shore with two young ladies their daughters, Mrs Norman, Mr and Mrs Barclay, and Mr Chauntry an eminent sculptor formed the company with the family, including Mr Petty Vaughan.— We came home about one in the Morning— Received Notes from Messrs: G. & H. Joy, Allston and Leslie; answering invitations to dinner next Saturday. They accept.— Coll. Sarrasin de Maraise, has a previous engagement— I received also, under cover from Lord Castlereagh, a printed copy of the Treaty of Marriage between the Princess Charlotte and the Prince of Saxe-Coburg.— When we returned home, Mrs Adams received a Letter from her Sister, Mrs Buchanan.

21. VIII:30. I propose to make one more attempt, probably the last to keep my journal free from arrears, and for that purpose to devote to it the first hours of the morning. At the same time I must prepare for the time, now certainly near at hand, when I shall be able to devote only one line to every day.— I wrote this morning a short Letter to Mr Russell at Stockholm, enclosing one for him, which Mr William Vaughan gave me yesterday— Went with Mrs Adams, and our three Sons to London, and saw the Pictures at the British Gallery. Pall-Mall— This is a collection of 125 Pictures of the Italian and Spanish Schools, sent to the Gallery by the members of the British Institution for promoting the fine Arts, to be exhibited to the Public, for six weeks or two Months— A shilling admittance is paid for each person— The Rooms are the same where the Shakespear Gallery was formerly exhibited— In the vestibule on the ground floor is a colossal Statue of Achilles, by Banks; said to be the best piece of sculpture, ever executed in England— The Pictures are all admirable; being selections of two or three from all the richest collections in this Country. There are nine of Raphael, besides two of the Cartoons from Hampton-Court. The miraculous draught of fishes, and Paul, preaching at Athens. five of Andrea del Sarto. Six of Murillo. Six of Guido. Nine of Titian, ten of Annibal Caracci, five of Claude, twelve, (including nine heads of Apostles) of Leonardo da Vinci.— Nine of Nicolas and six of G. Poussin. five of Paul Veronese, three of Velasquez and single pictures or more of Julio Romano, L. Carracci, Giorgione, Albano, Carlo Dolce, Parmegiano, Corregio, Salvator Rosa, and others of the greatest masters—but none of Michael Angelo—and not a picture of the Dutch, Flemish or English Schools— I never had much of the enthusiasm of virtu—and my sensations have much flattened since I spent three weeks upon the Dresden Gallery. I have seen nothing since, which has, made so much impression upon me; not even the collection of the Napoleon Museum, which I saw last year at Paris and which is now no more— This collection at the British Gallery has rather disappointed me; for though all the pictures are admirable, there is not one of the first Class of Paintings, unless the two Cartoons may be so called; and I had seen them before— The best pictures were those of Raphael, Murillo, Andrea del Sarto, and one of the Claude’s. The Rooms were full of company.— We walked from them to the Office in Craven-Street, where I found a man, stating himself to be an American, and applying for a Passport to go to the United States; but he had no evidence to shew that he was really an American— His pronunciation was not American, and he admitted that he had not been for many years in the United States— I sent him away to seek proof— Then came the Seamen belonging to the Susan of New-York; a vessel that has been condemned and sold, leaving the wages of the sailors unpaid.— They have applied to the Consul, and been turned away, and this was the
second time of their coming to me for relief. Their case is nearly the same as that of the Seamen of the Baltimore. I wrote a note recommending them to Coll: Aspinwall— Mr John Levett Harris had been at the Office, and left a Packet of despatches from the Secretary of State to me—one for Mr Russell at Stockholm, and one for Mr Eustis at the Hague— The Packet for me, contained a letter of Instructions, dated 21. May, and a Letter of the same date empowering me to negotiate a new Convention of Commerce with the British Government; together with a variety of other documents, which I fear will be to very little purpose— We returned home at the usual hour; about seven— George walked with me from Kew Bridge— After dinner we took half an hour’s walk in the Garden, and the rest of the Evening I was perusing and pondering over my despatches.

22. VII. After the Journal, I began a Letter to the Secretary of State, which I could not finish— In my morning walk, I called upon Dr Nicholas, and settled his account for the schooling of my three Sons, for the term just closed— The Doctor, and his two daughters, Caroline and Ellen, dined with us, with Messrs Allston, Dr Cooke; Harris, G Joy and Henry Joy, and Leslie— Mr Townes and Mr J. A. Smith sent apologies. the former being previously engaged; and the latter, staying in London to see Mrs Siddons, perform the part of Lady Macbeth; which she does this Evening in compliance with the desire of the Princess Charlotte, who has recovered from her late illness— Our company left us between eleven and twelve at Night— I received by the Post a packet from the Secretary of State, containing nothing but two Letters to him; one from Mr H. Clay, and the other from Mr W. H. Crawford both dated 5. April last. and relating to the proposal for increasing the Salaries of the Ministers of the United States in foreign Countries—with a statement of the Salaries paid by the British and French Governments to their Ambassadors and Ministers.— I received also a Letter from Messrs: Pitcairn and Brodie of Hamburg with information that they have shipped Bode’s Uranographia, to Dr Kirkland, President of Harvard University; according to my directions.

23. VIII. Received by this Morning’s Post, a Letter from Mr G. W. Erving, still at Paris. Attended Church with all the family. Prayers for the second Sunday after Trinity were read, by Mr Carr, and the Sermon was preached by Dr Bond; from Job XXXIII. verses 29. and 30. “Lo, all those things worketh God oftentimes with man—to bring back his soul from the pit, to be enlightened with the light of the living.” There is too much ambition of eloquence in Dr Bond’s delivery—his manner is affected; but his sermons both for substance, and style, are far superior to any others that I have heard in England— This was upon the benefits of affliction; It was sufficiently methodical; and written with great elegance— There was a contrasted view of the effects of Prosperity and of adversity upon Solomon, and upon Job, drawn with great Spirit, and the Sermon closed with a solemn and pathetic apostrophe, to the two classes of the auditory, the prosperous and the afflicted, exhorting them to return to their homes with the impressions suitable to their respective conditions— The former of beneficence to their fellow Creatures, and the latter of Consolation in their sorrows. I continued writing to the Secretary of State, but without finishing the Letter— After dinner we all made an attempt to walk in the Garden, but were driven in by the rain— Afterwards it cleared off, and I walked with George and Charles to Brentford and Ealing. Closed the Evening by reading with George, the second Act of Terence’s Phormio.

24. VII:15. Received by the morning Post, a Letter from Messrs. Pitcairn and Brodie’s at Hamburg—dated the 16th instant, with advice that they have shipped Bode’s Uranographia, on board the Goliah, Captain Thomas M. Pain, a different vessel from that mentioned in their former letter— But they have now enclosed the Bill of lading.— I answered Letters from G. A. Thompson, the author or compiler of a Dictionary of America, and the West-Indies in five Quarto Volumes with an Atlas of Arrowsmith’s Maps who wrote to ask me to subscribe to the work—to which I have consented—and from a Mr de Corbin de la Beaussonniere a French Officer, who requested to see me— I have appointed three O’Clock to-morrow. Finished my despatch to the Secretary of State, and returned to the attempt to retrieve the arrears at the close of the last Volume of my Journal— I wrote however not more than half a dozen lines, being called away to attend the poney races at Ealing Fair— The Fair began this day, and is to continue the two following. Mrs Adams and the children road and I walked to the races, which were on Ealing Dean Common. I missed the first of the three heats, by going first to Ealing Common by mistake— I saw the second and third heats, the last of which was tolerably well contested. We returned home to dinner. I received a Letter, from Joseph T. Price, a partner of the Foxes, at the Neath Abbey-Iron Works; Glamorganshire, about a Steam Engine, which they suppose to be wanted, for the Mint of the United States— R. W. Fox the Consul at Falmouth, had already written to me on the same Subject; but I had not otherwise heard that a Steam-Engine was wanted for the Mint— Received also a Note from J. A. Smith, saying that there are
dispatches for me at the Office, and enclosing a Card of Countess Jersey at Home this Evening; but as I understand it is quite optional to attend these Evening parties or Routs, or not, at one’s convenience, and that no answers are expected to the cards, I concluded not to go this Evening; but after a walk in the Garden, went with my wife and children again to see the Shews at the Fair upon Ealing Green. There were several of them but we went in only at Richardson’s, where we saw a Melodrama, called the Turkish Heroine; and a Pantomime of Harlequin’s rambles; with a Sailor’s song between the two. The whole Spectacle lasted about an hour; and finished just at ten O’Clock when we came home. The seats were at a shilling and at sixpence each. The Stage was under a tent erected on the green, and their house was quite full— They repeat the same performance three or four times each Evening.

25. V:45. The first Morning for several weeks that I have had several hours for writing before breakfast; I employed it on the last Volume of my Journal. By the morning Post I received a Letter signed Thomas Lack, who is assistant Secretary to the Board of Trade; being an answer to my Note of 22. May last to Mr Robinson, Vice-President of the Board; with information that the Lords of the Treasury have directed the Commissioners of the Customs to return any difference in the amount of Tonnage Duties, charged on American Vessels, beyond those charged on British Vessels under similar circumstances; but that no application for such return has yet been made for any American Vessel.— Also a Letter from Mr James Brown of Liverpool, stating that his brother writes him, that Dutton the mate of the Baltimore had not been as he had thought a Mate of Budd’s—but that the Note from W. and J. Brown, recommending Dutton to Captain Baker for a Mate, was written at the request of Baker himself.— After Breakfast I went in the Curricle to London; and found at the Office several Letters and despatches— The Letter from the Secretary of State of 3. May mentioned in the later dispatch brought by Mr Harris, and enclosing a copy of the Letter from John Dick, the district Attorney of the United States at New-Orleans, to Mr Monroe, refuting the assertions of the Spanish Minister Onis— A file of the National Intelligencer, from 18 April to 2. May— A Packet of Public Documents, and a new cypher, enclosed under a blank cover— These papers were all sent to the Office by Mr Grubb, who writes that he received them from the Master of the Virginia-Coffee House—he also refers me to his former request in behalf of Mr Matheson the reputed teacher who wants to exhibit his pupils before me— A Letter from Coll. Aspinwall, requesting a new order upon the Brothers Baring and Co. for £500 Sterling on Account of distressed American Seamen.— An impertinent begging letter from the Abbe Humblet— A Letter from Mr Russell at Stockholm of 10. June; enclosing one from Mr Harris at St: Petersburg of 1. June, Harris is still in the midst of his troubles—interdicted, attendance at Court, and he says the Emperor threatens to withdraw his Minister from the United States, unless reparation is made, for his Consul General Mr Kosloff’s having been arrested at Philadelphia— Mr Leslie had been at the Office and with his card had left two Cards, for Mr West’s friends to see the Marquis of Stafford’s and the Earl of Grosvenor’s Collections of Pictures; the former to-morrow and the latter next Friday— I answered Coll: Aspinwall’s Letter, and sent him the order on the Brother’s Baring and Co. for £500. and a copy of the Letter I had received this morning from the board of Trade— Captain Cunningham, Master of the Brig Susan of New-York, with his Mates and all his crew came to the Office, and were two full hours; stating all their respective grievances to me. He has sold the ship to pay for repairs and expences; and the Seamen have arrested him for their wages: his consignees at Liverpool have failed, and the former friends and correspondents of his owners, in London, decline advancing him any money upon his Bills— He wished me to obtain a discharge of the suit of the Seamen against him, which I declined, as he had deprived them of their other remedy by selling the ship. He produced the Accounts of the men, and they admitted them for the greatest part. The difference between them was so small that I recommended to them, to meet again at the Consul’s Office, and endeavour again to come to an agreement; but I told Captain Cunningham, I could see no other expedient than for him to find some person who would take his Bill upon his owners, and advance the money due for the wages, the whole of which did not amount to £100 Sterling.— A person came for my certificate to authenticate the Signature of Matthew Wood as Lord Mayor of London; upon the exemplification of the last Will of Joseph Donaldson, to be used in some judicial Court in the United States— The Will contains legacies to several persons there. I gave the certificate, simply that Mr Wood is Lord Mayor of London.
Mr J. L. Harris called at the Office. He is appointed Consul of the United States, at St: Petersburg, and is on his way thither in that capacity— He thinks of embarking in a vessel bound directly to that Port, and expects to sail next Saturday. He had been this morning to the Office with Mr Peticoles, a young man who was a fellow passenger with him from America. Mr Peticoles is the Son of a refugee from St Domingo in the United States; was born there, and brings a strong Letter of recommendation from Mr Monroe to Mr: West the Painter.— As he expected shortly to want a Passport to go to France, he had left this Letter at the Office for me to read— A Mr Laurence called likewise for a Passport, to go to the United States; and Captain Cunningham took one for himself and his boy.— I had intended to go this day into the City, but was detained by these visitors at the Office until half past-five-O’Clock; so that it was seven when I reached home, to dinner; and I had not even time for a walk— The boys had been at the second day’s races. After dinner we all went to the Fair— Saw a Magic Lanthern Exhibition at a penny a head; and Saunders’s Show, of Horsemanship, Tumbling, Tight and Slack-Rope dancing; all in the lowest Style— It was past Midnight before we got home.

26. VIII:30.
