Having no time before breakfast, the Journal of yesterday engaged me so long that I could do nothing upon the arrears of the last month— It was the third and last day of the Ealing Fair— At 2 O’Clock Mrs Adams and the three boys, went to see the Races— After four I walked out, the rain which had begun about noon, having held up, about half an hour— But before I reached the race ground, it had begun again, and I was obliged to betake myself to the Carriage— Young Wright was there. I was in time to see all the races except the first, which had been lost by Dr Nicholas’s son Frank— There were three others, but they were run with no great Spirit, the rain, which was incessant, having marred the race-ground. We sat down young Wright at his uncle’s on our return home— I received a Letter from Mr H. Jackson, our Chargé d’Affaires at Paris, enclosing one from General La Fayette, to Mr Benjamin de Constant. Jackson says that all Letters addressed by Post to the General, are opened at the Post-Office; of which Circumstance he wishes his friends to be informed. I had also a Letter from Mr Maury dated at Buxton the 24th. mentioning his intention to return the next day to Liverpool— I employed the Evening in examining his Accounts of disbursements for distressed American Seamen— Wrote a Letter in answer to two from Mr Grubb, concerning Mr. Matheson’s request; and an answer to a Letter from George M’Bride at Dublin; about the discrimination between British and American Vessels in the number of Passengers they are allowed to take— The Children spent the Evening at an amusement of their own.

27. VI:30. Wrote Letters to James Maury, Consul at Liverpool, to R. W. Fox, Consul at Falmouth, to Joseph T. Price at the Neath-Abbey-Iron-Works, to Pitcairn and Brodie’s and Co. at Hamburg, and to L. Harris, at St Petersburg, all in answer to Letters received from them. Finished also the Journal of 12 May in the last Volume.— Received Letters—from John L. Harris at the London Coffee-House; informing me that he intends to embark in the Brig Narcissus, for St Petersburg; expects to sail next Saturday, and will take any despatches that I may wish to send— From Andrew Gregg formerly a Senator in Congress from the State of Pennsylvania, while I was a Member from Massachusetts.— It is a Letter of introduction to a Mr Lawrence Bathurst, who he says claims to be a relation of Earl Bathurst, and wishes me, to put him in the way of obtaining access to the Earl— Mr Gregg adds that Bathurst says his principal object in visiting England is to claim some patrimonial Estate to which he thinks himself entitled; but that most probably he has also that of obtaining a gratuity from the Earl, and the other wealthy branches of his family— From E. Johnson, Comptroller of the Two-penny Post-Office; a printed notice, returning, opened, a Letter which Mrs Adams had written to Pio, and directed to Foley Street; where he was not to be found— He had however left a minute at Craven Street indicating Foley Street as the place where he lodged— Before dinner I walked with George to Ealing, and the Dean Common, where we found that they were still running the Scrub Races. The Booths at the Fair were partly taken down; but part of them still remained, for exhibition this Evening. We had been invited to an Evening party of Tea and Sandwiches at Mrs Elmsley’s— The hour appointed, was seven O’Clock— It was eight when we went; Mrs Adams, George and I; and we found all the company there— A very old Lady, named Mrs Bligh—Admiral Stevens and his Lady—Mr and Mrs Roberts, with whom I dined, some Months since, at Major Morison’s—Their Son Mr William Roberts, and his wife, a beautiful, and very amiable woman; two Miss Cuthbertson’s—Mrs Elmsley’s two daughters, and their Governess a Miss Magrath. Most of the company passed the Evening at Cards— I played Quadrille with Miss Cuthbertson, Admiral Stevens, and Mr William Roberts— Soon after ten we went in to a very handsome Supper, instead of the Sandwiches— After supper we conducted the two Miss Cuthbertson’s to their house, and came home shortly before twelve at Night.

28. VII:30. Had barely time to write the Journal of Yesterday, before Breakfast— Letter from Mr Grubb, to Mrs Adams, asking for the settlement of his account.— Went to London with Mrs Adams, and our three Sons— I took with me a check upon Martin, Son, and Martin, Bankers 68. Lombard Street, from Baring Brothers and Co. which I have had ever since the 20th: of May, without one opportunity of going into the City to receive it. I gave it to Mr J. A. Smith requesting him to receive it to-morrow, and at the same time to call at the Consul’s Office, N. 1. Bishopsgate Church-Yard, and settle Mr Grubb’s Bill, which I also gave him—and with it, the Letter to Mr Harris at St Petersburg, to be left with his nephew, John, at the London Coffee-House— I found at my Office in Craven Street, a Note from Lord Castlereagh, in answer to that I had addressed to him concerning the case of the Nanina.— It is an explicit refusal, to interfere with the proceedings in the Admiralty Court.— And Letters—from Mr Monroe, recommending Mr Henry Foxall, the former owner of the Cannon Foundery at Georgetown; Mr Foxall left the letter at the Office, and will call again—from A. H. Everett, at Amsterdam. He is upon his return to the United States; and expects to sail about the first of next Month— This Letter was left by Mr Oliver Everett who has returned from the Continent and is going to Liverpool—from Mr Greuhm, the Secretary of the Prussian Legation, enclosing one from the Chevalier de Llano at Berlin— Mr Greuhm informs me that he likewise forwarded to me the last Letter that I received from Mr de Llano— This Gentleman who has become a very assiduous Correspondent of mine, has I fear more liberality of principle than discretion— I find by this Letter that old Mr Beresford the English or Irish Clergyman whom we knew at St Petersburg, is again at Berlin, and has lent my Lectures to Mr Llano, who writes of them in too flattering terms—and lastly, from W. A. Kenrick, the second Mate of the Baltimore, representing himself to be sick, and in great distress, and imploring relief— There had also been at the office a Mr Birkbeck, who has the project of going out to make a settlement in the United States— Mr A. G. Goodlet, Mr P. Sanders, and Dr Bollmann, who is again here, had left Cards at the Office— After being engaged about an hour with these Papers, I went, with all the family to see Earl Grosvenor’s Collection of Pictures at his House in Upper Grosvenor Street N. 33. We were admitted by the Ticket procured for us by Mr Leslie, as Mr West’s Friends— The Pictures are in five large Rooms on the ground floor, and form one of the finest collections I ever saw— In the first Room are principally works of English Painters, and among them are the Death of Wolfe, and the Battles of La Hague, and of the Boyne by West—and the blue boy of Gainsborough— In the second, the largest and perhaps finest picture is the pursuit of Labon after Jacob by Murillo— But there are four Claudes— Two Morning’s and two Evenings— Allegorical representations, of the rise and decline of the Roman Empire— Three small alledged Raphael’s; but having nothing in them justifying the claim to my eyes— One of them however is a St. John Baptist in the desart, which if genuine is the original of all the fine wild figured baptists, since painted— A tribute money by Titian, copied as I take it from the two copies of the same Picture in the Dresden Gallery.— A Madona and Child by Guido; a Marriage Feast by Paul Veronese; an Arcas and Calisto by Poussin, and others of less Note— In the third Room is Ixion embracing the Cloud by Rubens; an excellent Holy Family by Andrea del Sarto—the Sacrifice of the Israelites to the golden Calf, by Claude, and another smaller landscape by the same. A woman taken in Adultery, by Titian— A large and excellent Teniers, containing a Portrait of Teniers. a Meeting of David & Abigail by Poussin, and a Landscape with the Story of Jupiter and Antiope by Titian— In the fourth room five Portraits by Rembrandt, including his own—a salutation by Rembrandt— One Cattle piece, much admired, by Paul Potter, and one by Van der Velde—Dead Game, two pictures by Cuyp, and sundry dutch Landscapes and water Pieces. In the fifth Room is a large Picture by Snyders; a battle between two Bears, and a pack of Hounds, perhaps the most perfectly executed piece of the whole collection— The adoration of the three kings, by Rubens, likewise an Admirable Picture; a Madona and Child by Raphael, in his second manner— A Christ and the Samaritan woman at the Well, which Mr Leslie told me was a poor Picture—it was by Mignard— A marriage of St. Catherine, by Vandyke— And a little Prince riding on a large clumsy horse by Velasquez— There were many other pictures of inferior note, and smaller size— As I went in, I met Baron Just, the Saxon Minister coming out— He told me he had received a Letter from General Watzdorf, and intended to call upon us in the Country— We also met at the Rooms, Mr Henry Joy; and Mr Peticoles; and Mrs Adams met her old acquaintance Catherine Bancroft, youngest daughter of Dr Bancroft. We spent about two hours at the rooms, and then walked back to Craven Street, where I found Company— Mr G. Joy who finding me engaged immediately went away— Mr Corbin de la Beaussonniere, Frenchman, and formerly military Officer, with another person of the same description. Their object was to
enquire if there was any encouragement for them to go and offer their services to the United States? Whether I would pay for their passages? or whether they could expect to obtain Commissions, if they should go at their own expence— I told them that I had no authority to pay for the passage of any person; and that from the peculiar circumstances of the Country, there would be very little chance for any foreigner to obtain a military Commission there— They asked me, if I could give them a Passport. I said I thought they could now go, without any Passport; but if any one was necessary, they must have it from the French Ambassador— They doubted whether he would give them one, and left me, saying they were disappointed in their hopes— We had met Mr Laurence Bathurst almost at the door of the Office, and he returned to it with us— He now told me his Story and shewed me some of his Papers— He appeared from them to be a son of Sir Laurence Bathurst Baronet, who was son of a Sir Francis Bathurst, who was one of the original settlers of the Colony of Georgia; and as he says, a Brother of the first Allen Lord Bathurst— He tells a confused Story about his father, and strongly intimated that what there was to tell of him, particularly in his younger years, was not good— His main object is to obtain access to Earl Bathurst— I advised him to write a Note to the Earl, stating who he is, and asking to see him—with which I told him I had no doubt the Earl would comply— I said he might state that if the Earl would wish for evidence that he was what he claimed to be, he might refer to me; and assured him that I should be glad if I could be of any service to him— He said that after making his application to Earl Bathurst, he would call upon me again— We made a hasty cold dinner and then went to Miss S. Booth’s benefit, at Covent-Garden Theatre. The Play was Shakespear’s As you like it— We arrived after the Play had begun—at the second scene. Miss Booth herself performed the part of Rosalind—Charles Kemble, Orlando—Fawcott Touchstone, Young, Jaques, and Murray Old Adam.— Like Others of the best of Shakespear’s reading Plays, it disappointed me in the performance— Miss Booth’s Rosalind particularly fell short of my expectations— She sung the cuckoo song however very well, and was encored— Duruset sung the other two Songs, Blow, blow thou Winter’s Wind—and Under the Greenwood tree, delightfully. There was not enough of the humorist in Jaques, nor of the fool in Touchstone. Several of the finest passages in the Play were omitted; particularly the satirical strokes of Jaques, upon Pride, and the City woman, and the fine speech of the banished Duke, at the beginning of the 2d. Act. But there was a transposition still more improper of the description by one of the banished Lords, of the wounded stag, and the reflections of Jaques upon it; for they have put the narrative of this Lord, and the repetition of the good sayings of Jaques, into his own mouth, which is a total depravation of his character, changing him from the melancholy humorist, into a vain and impertinent coxcomb— The masque in the fifth Act was flat; and Miss Booth spoke the original Epilogue; where she said instead of if I were a woman—if I were among you, I would kiss as many of you, as had beards that pleased me &c as if any of the audience had any beards— After the Play Egerton came forward and announced for to-morrow Evening Henry the 8th. for the benefit of the fund for decayed actors; and stated that on this occasion Mrs Siddons had kindly consented to perform the part of Queen Catherine— Upon which there was a considerable hissing among a part of the Audience—others clapped; but the marks of disapprobation were stronger than those of applause. Mrs Siddons about two years since took formal leave of the Stage, but has lately reappeared already twice, and now comes for the third time— And no small part of the Public, question the propriety of this re-appearance; and although it is generally admitted that she is superior still to any other performer now on the Stage; they seem to consider it as a sort of offence against the public, after having once taken leave of them, that she still obtrudes her excellence upon their notice.— Between the hissing and the clapping, there arose a brawl in the Pit just before our box, in which there was an attempt to turn a man out—some pulling and hauling, and one or two fisty-cuff blows given; but the man kept his seat, and the Peace was restored by the appearance of Sinclair & Miss Stephens, who sung Boyce’s duet “together let us range,[”] which was followed by an Interlude called the Rival Soldiers—silly like all the modern English farces; but in which Matthews had a good part of a low lived Drunken fellow, in which he exercised humorously enough his powers of mimicry— He sung two songs, one A Lass is Good and a Glass is good, and the other, the Royal Visitors— Four-and twenty-Visitors all in a Row, much to the entertainment of the Company.— The Melo-Drama of the Blind Boy came next—the part of Edmund, by Miss S. Booth—then the Dance from Mother Goose by Grimaldi and Ellar; and lastly Ellar flew, or rather swung down from the Back of the Gallery, to the extremity of the Stage, by a Rope— It was at least half past twelve at Night when the whole was finished— We called at Craven Street, and thence came home— We arrived about three in the morning, and with broad day-light. I brought out with me Judge Story’s address to the Grand Jury of the U.S. Circuit Court, containing the biographical notices, concerning Mr Samuel Dexter; a pamphlet which Coll. Aspinwall had sent me—and Say’s pamphlet, de l’Angleterre, et des Anglois, which Mr G. Joy had left at the Office.— I left Lord Castlereagh’s Note concerning the case of the Nanina, at the Office, to be copied by Mr Smith. It was almost Sun rise, when we retired to bed.

29. IX:30. Much of the morning wasted; a necessary consequence of the fatiguing dissipations of yesterday and last Night. I read Judge Story’s eulogium upon S. Dexter; which is a handsome and just tribute of respect to his Memory— Wrote an answer to the letter from the Prussian Secretary of Legation, Mr Greuhm; and a Letter to R. W. Fox, the Consul at Falmouth, concerning the applications for relief of Kenrick, late Second Mate of the Baltimore. Journalizing the remainder of the day, without being able to get through the narrative of yesterday— A short walk to Brentford before dinner.— Saw the boys perform a Scene of Much Ado about Nothing, in the Evening, and read Say’s pamphlet— After which I read with George the third Act of Terence’s Phormio.

30. VIII:15. Unwell with a Cold, and my hand so much affected, that I write with extreme difficulty. Received a Letter from Coll. Aspinwall. Captain Cunningham has not made his arrangement with his Seamen, and is in prison at their suit. the Coll: recommends that they should discharge the suit against him, and resort to the ship, which he has sold, to pay other debts— I attended Church this morning, with my Sons George and Charles— Prayers were read by Mr Millman, for the third Sunday after Trinity. Dr Wallington preached the Sermon, from Luke XV:7. I say unto you, that likewise joy shall be in heaven over one sinner that repenteth, more than over ninety and nine just persons, which need no repentance.— It was a well written discourse in the most temperate Style, regularly constructed, with an introduction, and a natural division into three heads. The language was plain, with little ornament, and without any attempt at pathos. He cautioned his hearers against a misconstruction of the latter part of the text, as if there were any person who needed no repentance; and referred to the expositions of judicious Commentators to explain the proper meaning of the expressions— He shewed what kind of persons were to be understood by the term Sinners, and how they were to be saved by repentance— One of the strongest marks that I have of the merit of a Sermon is, to find attention possible without effort, and without involuntary wanderings. I listened to the whole of this, without difficulty— Mrs Adams went to Clapham, and paid a visit to Mrs Von Harten— Her husband is not yet released from prison. Antoine and the boys, found two young Cuckows, one in the Nest of a Nightengale, with a single Nightengale’s egg, and the other in the Nest of a Robin. I walked before dinner to Brentford, and after dinner with my wife and all the boys, in our own garden.

Day. I have been into London, almost every other day throughout the Month.— And more than half the time at dinner, or Evening parties, from which I returned always after Midnight—often by broad morning day-light.— The necessary consequence has been late rising hours the subsequent days, and the actual consequence late rising hours generally.— Hence a relaxation of Industry—accumulated arrears of Correspondence, and the impossibility of retrieving those of my Journal for the last Month. I have barely succeeded in keeping along with the current of this— I have scarcely ever risen so early as six, and once as late as ten— The hours before breakfast have thus been in a great measure lost, and on the days when I go into London, they are commonly the only hours that I have for writing.— We Breakfast between ten and eleven, and dine at six, or when I return from London to dinner, at seven. All the time that I have at home, is devoted to writing Letters and my Journal, excepting, about an hour every morning to read the daily Newspapers—the Morning Chronicle of the Day, and the Courier of the preceding Evening, and on Sunday’s the Observer and Cobbett’s Register.— Sunday Morning’s, I always attend the Church at Ealing— After dinner, I must be idle— In these long days we sometimes walk in our garden, and sometimes round the neighbourhood— I seldom retire to bed, until near Midnight— The Season has been backward, almost beyond example— There has been yet scarcely a day of warm weather; but the face of the Country has been exquisitely beautiful— Our garden though small, is laid out with taste and elegance, with forest trees, fruit-trees, shrubs, Plants, herbs, kitchen vegetables, and flowers in profusion— It is a little Paradise, vocal with the harmony of every feathered songster of the Spring— The Session of Parliament is just about closing. The fashionable world is deserting the City, and I hope henceforth for several Months to have no calls to London, other than of business or of curiosity— That I may be thus enabled to resume my hours of early rising, redeem my arrears of Correspondence, and of Journal, and find an occasional hour for useful reading.— The Season of hay-making is just now commencing, and within the last five days we have the first peas and strawberries from our Garden.— My three Sons are now all at home and in vacation— They are to continue so through the whole of the ensuing Month; but I can neither find nor make leisure to employ their time advantageously for themselves.
